Award.AwardTitle: I/UCRC CGI: Collaborative Research: Wood-Based Composites Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
/UCRC for Wood-Based Composites Center

1035009 Virginia Polytechnic; Charles Frazier
1034975 Oregon State University; Frederick Kamke

The Center for Wood-Based Composites will focus on advancing the material science of wood and wood-based composites. Virginia Polytechnic (VT) and Oregon State University (OSU) are collaborating to establish the proposed center, with VT as the lead institution.

The proposed Center will advance the materials science of wood and wood-based composites, by improving the understanding of how wood interacts with adhesives, sealants, and composite manufacturing variables. The Center will promote research in building systems, mechanical and adhesive fastening between wood and non-wood materials, as well as novel material testing and modeling. The PIs also intend to further establish an internationally recognized research center that can help shape public policy, as related to timber management, reforestation, and the reduction of fossil fuel usage by using the advanced products. The two institutions involved in the proposed center have experience in working with industrial partners and conducting research projects.

The development of more advanced wood-based composites to be used in applications that currently depend primarily on steel, aluminum or concrete would have a positive impact on the environment and help combat climate change. The proposed Center plans to attract graduate and undergraduate students from a variety of disciplines, and to provide them with an opportunity to interact with industry leaders, thus giving them an understanding of how to apply and transfer fundamental research and impact the industry and the economy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The vision of the NSF Industry/University Cooperative Research Center for Wood Based Composites is to be the leading source for fundamental research and education in the field of wood-based composites. These composites include such products as plywood, laminated veneer lumber, cross-laminated timber, particleboard, fiberboard and similar products, as well as new products that are currently under development. We actively promote and coordinate wood-based composites research and education at Virginia Tech and Oregon State University, as well as other university partners. We also attract students to careers in the wood-based composites and adhesion industries and provide continuing education programs.

The Center has advanced the material science of wood and wood-based composites by improving our understanding of how wood interacts with adhesives, coatings, and composite manufacturing variables. This has been accomplished through pre-competitive research under the advisement of company representatives from the adhesives and composite manufacturing industries. At Oregon State University and our collaborators, our research has revealed how various adhesive products penetrate into the porous network of wood cells, and how this penetration enhances the performance of adhesive bonds.  We were the first to apply advanced micro X-ray computed tomography techniques to generate three-dimensional characterization of adhesive bonds. This information was then used to create computer models to predict bond performance, thus allowing adhesive formulators to adjust their products to improve the strength and durability of wood composites. Other research has improved technology for blending adhesive with particulate composites, thus reducing adhesive consumption. Another project demonstrated how low grade veneer could be used for structural applications.  While other ongoing research is developing new methods to assess the long-term durability of wood composite products. In total, 10 multi-year research projects have been completed or ongoing at Oregon State University.

Timeless needs for warmth and shelter have made timber resources essential for human endeavor. Fossil fuels have supplanted wood for heating, but housing in North American still relies mostly on forest resources. The huge timbers that our ancestors needed are no longer available, and yet society’s reliance on wood-based materials is far greater today. Currently, composite materials are produced from smaller trees, plantation grown trees, and previously discarded trees. Wood is reduced to particles, flakes, strands, and sheets, and then reconsolidated to make composite beams, columns, panels, and many other products. This approach optimizes resource efficiency and also material performance. Opportunity lies not only in new shelter, but also in warmth and security through energy efficiency and carbon sequestration. In their manufacture, wood products consume far less fossil fuel than competitive materials. Furthermore, as CO2-reduction strategies develop, policy-makers and the public will realize that promotion of the forest products industry is an effective Earth-friendly strategy for carbon sequestration. Wise timber management, accelerated reforestation and afforestation, and the simultaneous transfer of carbon to durable wood products will play an essential role in CO2 reduction.

The Center not only stimulates technology, but also contributes to advancing societal goals by attracting graduate and undergraduate students from a variety of disciplines, including chemistry, materials science, engineering mechanics, civil engineering, and wood science, and then matriculating them through a rich and robust educational experience. Through graduate education and undergraduate research, the Center broadens the awareness of future scientists who otherwise would be unaware of the personal and societal rewards found in the wise use of timber resources. With financial support provided by the Center at Oregon State University, nine graduate students have completed their degrees, with five in progress as of the date of this report.

Modified by: Frederick A Kamke
